tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: I give praise to Yahweh with all my life, and with all that is within me, I give praise to his holy name
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how much he will praise Yahweh. AT: "I will praise Yahweh with all that I am" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: give praise to his holy name
tn.text: This refers to praising Yahweh's name as Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"all of me" or "all that I am." David uses this phrase to refer to himself and to emphasize his devotion to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Many translations express this with "my, I, me" as the UDB does.

tn.ref: He redeems your life from destruction
tn.text: This means that Yahweh keeps him alive. AT: "He saves me from dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "blessing" is described as if it were "crowning." AT: "he blesses you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He satisfies your life with good things
tn.text: The phrase "your life" refers to "you," but it emphasizes that Yahweh gives blessings throughout life. AT: "He satisfies you with good things through your life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: your youth is renewed like the eagle
tn.text: Having your "youth renewed" means to feel young again. Here David compares this feeling of youth to the swiftness and strength of an eagle. AT: "you feel young and are strong like an eagle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"youth" is referring to the strength one had as a young adult. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"causes justice to happen to"
Who is doing the oppressing can be stated explicitly. AT: "​all ​who are oppressed by men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The missing words may be added. AT: "he made known his deeds to the descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"is full of mercy and love"

tn.ref: He will not always discipline; he is not always angry
tn.text: These two phrases have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: He does not deal with us ... or repay us
tn.text: These two phrases are parallel and emphasize that God does not punish us as we deserve. AT: "He does not repay us with the punishment we deserve for our sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"punish us"

tn.ref: For as the skies are high ... toward those who honor him
tn.text: The simile compares the great distance between heaven and earth to the greatness of God's love for his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: As far as the east ... removed the guilt of our sins from us
tn.text: The distance between east and west is so far that it cannot be measured. In this simile, that distance is being compared to how far God moves our guilt away from us. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: As a father has compassion ... on those who honor him
tn.text: Here the author compares a father's compassion for his children to Yahweh's compassion for those who honor him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "what our bodies are like" or "how he formed our bodies" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: he knows that we are dust
tn.text: When Yahweh created Adam the first man he created him from dust. AT: "he remembers that he created us from dust" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: As for man, his days are like grass
tn.text: In this simile, the length of man's life is being compared to the short length of time that grass grows before it dies. AT: "The length of man's life is short like that of grass" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: he flourishes like a flower in a field
tn.text: In this simile, how man grows over time is compared to how a flower grows. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
To "flourish" is to grow well or be healthy.

tn.ref: The wind blows over it, and it disappears ... where it once grew
tn.text: These phrases continue to talk about flowers and grass. They compare how flowers and grass die to how man dies. AT: "The wind blows over the flowers and grass and they disappear, and no one can tell where they once grew—it is the same way with man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This means that Yahweh's love continues forever. AT: "will continue forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
"the descendants of those who honor him"

tn.ref: They keep his covenant and remember to obey his instructions
tn.text: These two phrases have similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Yahweh has established his throne in the heavens
tn.text: Here Yahweh's reign as king is referred to as his "throne." AT: "Yahweh has taken his seat in the heavens where he rules as king" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"made"
Here Yahweh is referred to by "his kingdom" to emphasize his authority as king. AT: "he rules" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom meaning to "do his will." AT: "do his will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: in all the places where he reigns
tn.text: "praise him in all the places where he reigns"
"with all of me" or "with all my soul." This phrase means that he will praise Yahweh wholeheartedly and is used to emphasize his devotion to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
